instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.A1465: What is A1465? A1465 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2924, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00164, 820-3208, 820-3435..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: (RESOLVED) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>, replaced, then 2 weeks later burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi all.
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Air with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A logic board that is dead.

I recently had this unit it, dead, and found <CAPACITOR>C7510</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> Rail was visibly damaged - burnt, and had shorted out that rail.
I removed it, the short was gone, so I replaced with another from a spares board.
The unit appeared to work perfectly, so I returned it to the customer.

Two weeks later, the customer brings it back in, dead again.

This time there is a damaged cap (<CAPACITOR>C7284</CAPACITOR>) on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>, that is burnt, and shorted.

Both <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> show a short to ground, however after removing <CAPACITOR>C7284</CAPACITOR>, the short has disappeared.

What should I be looking forward that would cause this?
I could just replace <CAPACITOR>C7284</CAPACITOR>, but I suspect something is drawing too much current?
Or is it just bad luck/timing?
Any suggestions greatly appreciated.

threads.title: (RESOLVED) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>, replaced, then 2 weeks later burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Strange to happen so quick in time; but could be just bad luck.
Did you check the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, without battery connected?

threads.title: (RESOLVED) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>, replaced, then 2 weeks later burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos.
Thanks for your input.

With <CAPACITOR>C7284</CAPACITOR> removed, the short is gone.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is low - it seems to fluctuate between 4.05 and 4.19 volts, every second or so - fast enough to notice on a multimeter.
Battery disconnected.

Magsafe light on connect is green then goes orange.
Unit does not power on.
Nothing seems hot to touch.

I guess I'll start looking at why <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is low...

threads.title: (RESOLVED) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>, replaced, then 2 weeks later burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Start checking resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

Try starting in SMC bypass mode too.

threads.title: (RESOLVED) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>, replaced, then 2 weeks later burnt cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Update:
OK, above measurement was at F9700

If I measure <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on pin 1 of F9700, the figure is ~4 volts.
This is the same as pin 2 of F7040.

HOWEVER, pin 1 of fuse F7040 measures 8.42 volts as it should for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I thought fuses either worked or they didn't?

I removed the fuse, and it measures 15 Ohms?
Weird.
I replaced it with another from a spares board, and unit is now running, boots to OSX, and seems fine.
I haven't yet replaced <CAPACITOR>C7284</CAPACITOR>

Thanks again for your help 2informaticos, I appreciate it.
